security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill that instructs the AI to run linters. The skill itself contains no executable code - it only provides instructions to the AI. The actual security risk depends on the AI's implementation of the linters command and the tools it has access to (Bash, Read, Edit).

low_findings.title: External command execution via linters
low_findings.description: The skill instructs the AI to run the 'linters' command which executes external processes. While this is expected behavior for a linting tool, it represents a capability that could be misused if the AI's linters implementation is compromised.

content.user_title: Run Linters to Fix Code Quality Issues
content.value_statement: Code linting catches bugs and style issues before they reach production. This skill automatically runs your project's linters and fixes any issues it finds.
actual_capabilities: Runs linters command to check code quality
Fixes linting issues using Edit tool
limitations: Requires linters to be configured in the repository
Cannot fix complex linting rule violations automatically
May need user input for rule configuration decisions

use_cases.title: Pre-commit Code Quality Check
use_cases.description: Run linters before committing code to ensure consistent style and catch potential bugs

use_cases.title: Automated Code Review Prep
use_cases.description: Automatically fix linting issues in pull requests before human review

use_cases.title: CI/CD Pipeline Integration
use_cases.description: Integrate linting checks into development workflows for consistent code quality

prompt_templates.title: Basic Linting
prompt_templates.prompt: I just finished making changes to my code. Please run the linters to check for any issues.

prompt_templates.title: Fix All Issues
prompt_templates.prompt: The linters found several issues. Please read the affected files and fix all the linting errors automatically.

prompt_templates.title: Specific Linter
prompt_templates.prompt: Run ESLint on the src/ directory and fix any JavaScript style issues you find.

prompt_templates.title: Pre-commit Check
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm about to commit these changes. Run all linters first and ensure there are no issues before I proceed.

best_practices: Run linters after completing a logical set of changes, not after every small edit
Fix all linting issues before committing code to maintain code quality
Ask users before disabling any linting rules to ensure team standards are maintained
anti_patterns: Running linters after every single line change wastes time and interrupts flow
Ignoring linting errors leads to technical debt and inconsistent code
Disabling rules without team discussion can break project conventions

faq.question: Which linters does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill uses your project's configured linters including ESLint, RuboCop, Pylint, and others that are set up in your repository.

faq.question: Can it fix all types of linting errors?
faq.answer: It can fix most common issues like formatting, missing semicolons, and unused variables. Complex rule violations may require manual intervention.

faq.question: How does it integrate with my existing workflow?
faq.answer: The skill works with any repository that has linters configured. It reads your existing linter configurations and follows project rules.

faq.question: Is my code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill only reads and modifies files to fix linting issues. It doesn't send code externally or make network requests.

faq.question: What if the linter finds an issue I don't want to fix?
faq.answer: The skill will ask before making changes. You can specify which issues to fix or ask to skip certain rules.

faq.question: How is this different from running linters manually?
faq.answer: The skill automatically fixes issues for you, saving time compared to manually editing each file with linting errors.
